Title: Association between maternal exposure to perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and risks of adverse pregnancy outcomes: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Authors: Zhuoma Deji, Peng Liu, Xin Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuehua Luo, Zhenzhen Huang
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "this meta-analysis work based on twenty-one studies was intended to examine possible relationships between PFASs exposure in maternal period and three adverse pregnancy outcomes."
  - "The effect of maternal PFOS exposure on preterm birth was remarkable, while the effects of other kinds of PFASs were not obvious."
  - "The results of the meta-analysis indicated that maternal exposure to PFASs did not increase the risk of miscarriage."
  - "Twenty-one studies have been selected to assess the association between maternal exposure to PFASs and adverse pregnancy outcomes in this systematic review and meta-analysis."
  - "The first meta-analysis on maternal PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes was performed."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper explicitly states that it is the first meta-analysis on maternal PFASs exposure and adverse pregnancy outcomes, indicating a focus on PFASs.
- The systematic review and meta-analysis are specifically designed to explore the association between maternal exposure to PFASs and adverse pregnancy outcomes, which suggests a focus on PFASs.
- The paper mentions that twenty-one studies were selected to assess the association between maternal exposure to PFASs and adverse pregnancy outcomes, further indicating a focus on PFASs.
- The results and discussions throughout the paper are centered around the effects of PFASs on pregnancy outcomes, reinforcing the focus on PFASs.
- There is no mention of other chemicals being investigated in the context of this review, which supports the conclusion that the focus is solely on PFASs.

Title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINANT EXPOSURES AND PRETERM BIRTH: A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW
Authors: Kelly K Ferguson, Marie S O'neill, John D Meeker
Venue: Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health. Part B, Critical Reviews
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "Overall, the current literature examining associations between environmental contaminant exposures and preterm birth indicates suggestive evidence for effects of some exposures, while results for others are inconclusive:

(1) For POP, evidence is strong for a relationship between DDE exposure at high levels and preterm birth. Data are suggestive for DDE at lower levels and also for PFC, particularly in studies where biomarkers of exposure were used."
  - "A number of recent studies examined the relationship between PFOA and PFOS exposure and preterm birth."
  - "Perfluorinated chemicals repel oil, grease, and water and are used to treat carpets and clothing to prevent stains, and are also components of some food containers and wrappers (ATSDR, 2009) . Through product use and manufacturing they can be released into the environment, and do not degrade in soil or water. Exposure occurs through consumption of contaminated drinking water and food, inadvertent ingestion of indoor dust, and potentially through inhalation (ATSDR, 2009) . The two compounds produced in largest quantities include perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) and perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS)."
  - "Using PubMed searches, studies were identified that examined associations between preterm birth and exposure to five categories of environmental toxicants, including persistent organic pollutants, drinking-water contaminants, atmospheric pollutants, metals and metalloids, and other environmental contaminants."
  - "This is a comprehensive review of all known studies published from 1992 through August 2012 linking maternal exposure to environmental chemicals during pregnancy with preterm birth."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper is a comprehensive review of studies linking maternal exposure to various environmental chemicals with preterm birth, indicating it covers a broad range of chemicals.
- The review includes five categories of environmental toxicants, which suggests a broad focus rather than a specific focus on PFAS.
- The paper does discuss PFAS, specifically PFOA and PFOS, indicating that PFAS are included in the review.
- The mention of "suggestive evidence for effects of some exposures" and specific mention of PFC (which includes PFAS) suggests that PFAS are part of the review but not the sole focus.

Title: Early-Life Exposure to Per-and Poly-Fluorinated Alkyl Substances and Growth, Adiposity, and Puberty in Children: A Systematic Review
Authors: Yun Jeong Lee, Hae Woon, Hwa Young Kim, Yoon-Jung Choi, Young Ah Lee, Alberto Mantovani
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "We performed a systematic review of the epidemiologic literature to assess the effects of earlylife PFAS exposure on prenatal and postnatal growth, adiposity, and puberty in children and adolescents."
  - "Exposure was defined as exposure to PFOA, PFNA, PFDA, PFUnDA, PFDoDA, perfluorotridecanoic acid (PFTrDA), perfluorotetradecanoic acid (PFTeDA), perfluorohexadecanoic acid (PFHxDA), PFOS, PFHpS, PFHxS, perfluorodecane sulfonic acid (PFDS), pentafluorobenzoic acid (PFBA), perfluoropentanoic acid (PFPeA), perfluorohexanoic acid (PFHxA), perfluoroheptanoic acid (PFHpA), perfluorobutane sulfonic acid (PFBS), perfluorooctane sulfonamide (PFOSA), N-ethyl-perfluorooctane sulfonamidoacetic acid (Et-PFOSA-AcOH), or N-methyl-perfluorooctane sulfonamidoacetic acid (Me-PFOSA-AcOH)."
  - "The selection criteria were 1) cohort studies or casecontrol studies which investigated the effects of PFAS on growth, adiposity, or puberty in children and adolescents, 2) primary research articles in English and published in peer-reviewed journals."
  - "The 90 studies were comprised of 62 cohort studies, 22 crosssectional studies, and 6 case-control studies."
  - "The effects of prenatal PFAS exposures on fetal growth have been much studied over the past few decades."
  - "In this review, we focused on the effects of prenatal to postnatal PFAS exposures on growth, adiposity, and puberty in children and adolescents."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper explicitly states that it is a systematic review focused on the effects of early-life PFAS exposure on growth, adiposity, and puberty in children and adolescents. This indicates that the primary focus is on PFAS.
- The exposure definition provided in the paper lists various PFAS substances, which further supports that the review is focused on PFAS.
- The selection criteria for studies included in the review specify that they must investigate the effects of PFAS, reinforcing the focus on PFAS.
- The paper does not mention any other chemicals being investigated alongside PFAS, suggesting that PFAS is the sole focus.

Title: Human exposure pathways to poly-and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from indoor media: A systematic review
Authors: Nicole M Deluca, Jeffrey M Minucci, Ashley Mullikin, Rachel Slover, Elaine A Cohen Hubal, Adrian Covaci, B S T R A C T
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "Human exposure to per-and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) has been primarily attributed to contaminated food and drinking water."
  - "This systematic review (SR) synthesizes evidence for exposure from indoor residential pathways to inform understanding of variability in serum PFAS levels in the general population from sources other than drinking water and diet."
  - "A subset of well-studied substancesperfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), perfluorooctanesulfonate (PFOS), perfluorobutanoic acid (PFBA), perfluorobutane sulfonate (PFBS), perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA), perfluorohexanoic acid (PFHxA), perfluorohexanesulfonate (PFHxS), and perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA)were targeted in the literature for subsequent analysis."
  - "The objective of this study was to evaluate evidence of PFAS exposure pathways in the residential environment by considering the relationship between occurrence of PFAS chemicals indoors and levels of these chemicals in serum."
  - "The study focuses on a subset of relatively well-studied PFAS chemicals including perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), perfluorooctanesulfonate (PFOS), perfluorobutanoic acid (PFBA), perfluorobutane sulfonate (PFBS), perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA), perfluorohexanoic acid (PFHxA), perfluorohexanesulfonate (PFHxS), and perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA)."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper explicitly states that it is focused on human exposure to PFAS, specifically from indoor residential pathways.
- The systematic review targets a subset of well-studied PFAS chemicals, indicating a focus on these substances.
- The objective of the study is to evaluate PFAS exposure pathways, further confirming the focus on PFAS.
- The PECO criteria table specifies that the exposures of interest are measured occurrences of specific PFAS chemicals in indoor media, reinforcing the focus on PFAS.

Title: Legacy and emerging pollutants in Latin America: A critical review of occurrence and levels in environmental and food samples

Three noble metals, platinum (Pt), palladium (Pd), and rhodium (Rb), were also included."

Title: Organic Contaminants in Chinese Sewage Sludge: A Meta-Analysis of the Literature of the Past 30 Years
Authors: Xiang-Zhou Meng, Arjun K Venkatesan, Yi-Lin Ni, Joshua C Steele, Ling-Ling Wu, Anders Bignert, Åke Bergman, Rolf U Halden
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "Since 1987, 35 classes of chemicals consisting of 749 individual compounds and 1 mixture have been analyzed, in which antibiotics and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) were the most targeted analytes."
  - "For 13 classes of principal OCs (defined as chemicals detected in over five studies) in sludge, the median (expressed in nanograms per gram dry weight) was the highest for phthalate esters (27 900), followed by alkylphenol polyethoxylates (12 000), synthetic musks (5800), antibiotics (4240), PAHs (3490), ultraviolet stabilizers (670), bisphenol analogs (160), organochlorine pesticides (110), polybrominated diphenyl ethers (100), pharmaceuticals (84), hormones (69), perfluorinated compounds (21), and polychlorinated biphenyls (15)."
  - "Thirty-five classes of organic contaminants, including 749 individual compounds and 1 mixture (short chain chlorinated paraffins (SCCPs); generally reported in mixture), have been analyzed in Chinese sludge since 1987"
  - "The EU proposed an MTC for di(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (100 000 ng/ g dw) in sludge applied to soil, and that MTC is very close to the mean value found in Shanghai samples (97 400 ng/g dw)."
  - "The MTC for 4-nonylphenol (50 000 ng/g dw), an abundant chemical found in Chinese sludge, was also proposed in the third draft of the EU Sludge Directive."
  - "The findings and database of this study could serve as a useful tool for researchers, policy makers, and industry professionals. By using sludge as a suitable matrix for capturing human activities and ecological impacts, more knowledge will result from monitoring geographic and temporal trends of OCs in sludge, in the environment, 189,190 and ultimately in human populations."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper is a meta-analysis of organic contaminants (OCs) in Chinese sewage sludge, covering a wide range of chemicals.
- The focus is on various classes of OCs, including antibiotics, PAHs, phthalate esters, and others, as indicated by the list of principal OCs.
- Perfluorinated compounds (PFCs) are mentioned as one of the classes of OCs analyzed, but they are not the primary focus of the study.
- The paper discusses the concentrations and trends of various OCs, including PFCs, but does not specifically focus on PFAS as a primary area of investigation.
- The tables included in the paper provide detailed information on various OCs, but again, PFAS is not highlighted as a primary focus.

Title: Perfluoroalkyl substances and lipid concentrations in the blood: A systematic review of epidemiological studies
Authors: Soon Hoe Ho, Stacy Xin, Hui Soh, Min Xian Wang, Janet Ong, Annabel Seah, Yvonne Wong, Zhanxiong Fang, Shuzhen Sim, Jue Tao Lim, C L E I N F O, Adrian Covaci
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "We did not set any limit on the type of PFAS reviewed in order to broaden our coverage, and focussed specifically on peer-reviewed articles to ensure the validity of the findings; hence grey literature was excluded."
  - "Given that we excluded polyfluoroalkyl substances from the review even though they are commonly categorised under the term "PFAS" together with perfluoroalkyl substances (Buck et al., 2011), our review is more focused in terms of the assessed exposures."
  - "This review will include perfluoroalkyl substances such as perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (PFOS) and perfluorohexanesulfonic acid (PFHxS), but exclude polyfluoroalkyl substances like perfluoroalkane sulfonamido substances and fluorotelomer substances."
  - "This systematic review aims to assess PFAS associations with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL), total cholesterol (TC) and total triglyceride (TG) concentrations in human populations."
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper explicitly states that its focus is on assessing the associations between PFAS and lipid concentrations in human populations, indicating a primary focus on PFAS.
- The review includes various types of PFAS but excludes polyfluoroalkyl substances, which are sometimes categorized under the broader term "PFAS." This suggests a specific focus on perfluoroalkyl substances.
- The authors mention that they did not limit the type of PFAS reviewed, which implies a comprehensive focus on PFAS as a class of compounds.
- The exclusion of grey literature and focus on peer-reviewed articles further supports the idea that the review is focused on PFAS.

Title: The Association between ADHD and Environmental Chemicals-A Scoping Review
Authors: Sonja Moore, Laura Paalan, Lisa Melym, Andromachi Katsonouri, Marike Kolossa-Gehring, Hanna Tolonen
Supporting quotes for "PFAS focus":
- "The focus of this scoping review was only on those selected as the priority substances of the HBM4EU project."
  - "The aim of this scoping review was to summarize known or possible associations between ADHD and environmental exposures related to HBM4EU priority substances."
  - "Only those HBM4EU priority substances were included in the current paper for which relevant reviews or meta-analyses on their associations with ADHD were found."
  - "Five studies in which exposure was assessed either before birth or during childhood were identified in another review with a broader outcome definition"
  - "Two studies on perfluoroalkyl compounds (PFCs) (i.e., PFASs) during childhood and ADHD were included in a review by Nilsen and Tulve (2020)"
Reasoning for "PFAS focus":
- The paper is a scoping review focused on summarizing associations between ADHD and environmental exposures related to HBM4EU priority substances.
- PFASs are mentioned as one of the substances with low evidence of association with ADHD, indicating that they are included in the review.
- The paper includes studies specifically examining PFASs, such as those by Nilsen and Tulve (2020), which suggests that PFASs are part of the review's focus.
- The review is not exclusively focused on PFASs but also investigates other chemicals as part of the HBM4EU priority substances.
- The paper's scope is broader than just PFASs, as it covers multiple chemicals and their associations with ADHD.
